I don't actually understand what's causing the problem here, but I don't think this is the right fix, for several reasons:

1. It adds more atomic operations for every call combiner start and stop, which probably has performance impact.
2. It makes the call combiner aware of the call, which violates the abstraction provided by call combiner; despite its name, the call combiner is really designed to be a generic mechanism, not something that is specific to calls.  (This is why it's in src/core/lib/iomgr instead of src/core/lib/surface.)
3. It should not be necessary to add refs to the call in the first place, since the code in surface/call.cc should already maintain a ref for every pending batch.

Can you help me understand what the actual problem is, in terms of what lines of code execute when?  I suspect that the right fix involves changing some code in surface/call.cc, but I can't say for sure without understanding the actual problem.

Actually, I just looked at the tsan failure in #15457, and I think the right fix is probably in the client_channel retry code.  But let me think about it a bit more.
This should probably be closed in favor of #15536.

So as I understand, the real problem is that the retry batch didn't hold a ref to the call. This PR prevents the data race because it makes whatever thing (including the retry batch) to run in the call combiner hold a ref to the call. And the right fix is to add ref to the call only for the retry batch. Correct?
